Do women actually travel more than men?
item.description:
Michael Story ⚓ (@MWStory) on X

I found this interesting because there’s not much to suggest that women actually do travel more than men (eg Pew 👇🏻). Thats consistent with enjoying it more when it happens ofc but conclusions resting on the data slicing you see in that post seem a bit shaky

URL: https://twitter.com/MWStory/status/1746746847664935302

item.title: Excellent Zach Mazlish tweets on the macro puzzle of our day
item.description:
Zach Mazlish (@ZMazlish) on X

Recent supply vs demand (dis)inflation squabbles miss the point. What is puzzling about ’23 is r >> r* suggested by last 15-years, yet output grew 3%. 4 possible explanations: 1) A net positive supply shock, not just unwinding of a negative one 2) fiscal policy sufficiently…

URL: https://twitter.com/ZMazlish/status/1746163370753978374

AI will underwhelm,
item.description:
Adam Ozimek (@ModeledBehavior) on X

Acemoglu warns AI will lead employers to do more workplace surveillance. Then he’s praising the Henry Ford approach. This is funny. Ford famously raised pay, but he also literally employed a Sociological Department of 150 inspectors to police the personal lives of his workers.

URL: https://twitter.com/ModeledBehavior/status/1745818045983965621?s=20

Chomba Bupe (@ChombaBupe) on X

An explanation for why GPT-4 is degrading: ”... we find that on datasets released before the LLM training data creation date, LLMs perform surprisingly better than on datasets released after” New tasks are difting away from what GPT-4 was trained on.

A Map for AI Town Planners, 2024-29
item.description:
This essay is part of the Mediocre Computing series. As many observers have noted, AI appears to be speedrunning the technological evolution curve. The Altman-OpenAI exit/return saga unfolding in days, compared to the Jobs-Apple exit/return saga unfolding over years, was a particularly dramatic motif for this observation. It is not…

item.title: Signs and Portents
item.description:
As we begin the second year of our AI Moment (it is still too early and dramatic to call it the AI Age), it is time to consider the future. To be clear, nobody can tell you the future of AI accurately, except that AI development seems to be happening much, much faster than even experts expected. We can be confident about that because a…

URL: https://www.oneusefulthing.org/p/signs-and-portents?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: LLM links

item.title: AI #45: To Be Determined
item.description:
The first half of the week was filled with continued talk about the New York Times lawsuit against OpenAI, which I covered in its own post. Then that talk seemed to mostly die down,, and things were relatively quiet. We got a bunch of predictions for 2024, and I experimented with prediction markets for many of them…

URL: https://thezvi.substack.com/p/ai-45-tbd?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: LLM links

item.title: Both sexes have to be oppressed
Conspicuous cognition
item.description:
This year, I am going to be blogging at this site. There are several reasons for this. I like writing. It helps me to clarify my thoughts about a topic. Blogs also provide a way of publicly engaging with ideas and debates that is separate from the long, soul-destroying process of academic publication. And I now have a permanent lectureship, which means …

URL: https://www.conspicuouscognition.com/p/conspicuous-cognition?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Links to Consider

item.title: Should I Have Had a Kid?
item.description:
“There’s no one right way to parent.” We repeat that often at ParentData, because it’s true. What’s not talked about as often is that there’s also no one right way to feel. Parenting is full of complex experiences and emotions. While there are joyful moments that feel fulfilling and even perfect, there are also moments that fill us with doubt, fear, sad…

URL: https://emilyoster.substack.com/p/should-i-have-had-a-kid?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Links to Consider

item.title: Creating insular information bubbles
item.description:
This is the fortieth piece in Lorenzo Warby’s series of essays on the strange and disorienting times in which we live. This article can be adumbrated thusly: Narratives are not about facts, they’re about making meaning. However, if they’re to continue to make meaning, they have to be protected from facts…

URL: https://www.notonyourteam.co.uk/p/creating-insular-information-bubbles?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Links to Consider
